conclusion: The work done by the gas during a cyclic process in a p-V diagram is equal to the area enclosed by the cycle.
The cycle is a triangle ABC with vertices A, B, and C having coordinates (V_A, p_A), (V_B, p_B), and (V_C, p_C).
From the diagram, V_A = 2 L, p_A = 1 x 10^5 Pa, V_B = 2 L, p_B = 4 x 10^5 Pa, V_C = 5 L, p_C = 1 x 10^5 Pa.
Convert volumes to cubic meters: V_A = 2 L = 2 x 10^-3 m^3, V_B = 2 L = 2 x 10^-3 m^3, V_C = 5 L = 5 x 10^-3 m^3.
The cycle is A→B→C→A. The work done is the area of the triangle ABC.
Calculate the area of the triangle using base and height, taking base as segment CA.
The line segment CA is horizontal at pressure p = 1 x 10^5 Pa, and its length is the change in volume from A to C, which is |V_C - V_A| = 3 x 10^-3 m^3.
The height of the triangle with respect to base CA is the perpendicular distance from point B to line segment CA, which is |p_B - p_A| = 3 x 10^5 Pa.
The area of the triangle is 1/2 x base x height = 1/2 x (3 x 10^-3 m^3) x (3 x 10^5 Pa) = 450 J.
Since the cycle is traversed in the clockwise direction (A→B→C→A), the net work done by the gas is positive.
Work done by the gas on the surroundings is W_cycle = + Area.
